TITLE: ATP vs CTP — Difference Between Available-to-Promise and Capable-to-Promise

SUMMARY
ATP (Available-to-Promise) answers: "Can we promise from existing inventory + scheduled receipts?" CTP (Capable-to-Promise) answers: "Can we promise by producing/procuring using available capacity within the timeframe?"

ATP (AVAILABLE-TO-PROMISE)
- based on on-hand inventory
- plus scheduled inbound receipts
- minus existing commitments
- best for make-to-stock environments

CTP (CAPABLE-TO-PROMISE)
- based on capacity (labor, machines, suppliers)
- considers lead times and constraints
- best for make-to-order or constrained supply

WHEN TO USE WHICH
- Use ATP for fast promise decisions when inventory is reliable
- Use CTP when inventory is insufficient but capacity planning can meet demand

TITLE: Escalation Ladder — Triggers in Project Management

SUMMARY
An escalation ladder defines when and how issues get escalated through owners and leadership to prevent missed milestones.

COMMON ESCALATION TRIGGERS
- blocker persists > 48 hours
- dependency slip threatens a milestone date
- scope change without approval impacts timeline/cost
- SEV incident impacts delivery or customer commitments
- repeated misses of weekly commitments

LADDER (example)
Owner → Tech lead → Manager → Director/VP → Exec sponsor

BEST PRACTICE
Escalate with a clear ask: decision needed, resources, or priority trade-off.

TITLE: RAID Log — What to Track and How to Review

SUMMARY
RAID = Risks, Assumptions, Issues, Dependencies. It is the single list of items that can derail delivery.

FIELDS
- type (R/A/I/D)
- description
- owner
- impact (H/M/L)
- probability (H/M/L) for risks
- next action + due date
- status

REVIEW CADENCE
- review weekly in the core execution meeting
- escalate high-impact items immediately

TITLE: Reorder Point (ROP) — Definition and Formula

SUMMARY
Reorder point (ROP) is the inventory level that triggers replenishment.

FORMULA (simple)
ROP = average demand during lead time + safety stock

NOTES
- longer lead times increase average demand during lead time
- higher variability requires higher safety stock

TITLE: SIM Provisioning Retry Policy — Recommended Defaults

SUMMARY
Use bounded retries with exponential backoff + jitter for transient failures during provisioning.

RETRYABLE
- timeouts
- 502/503/504
- transient 5xx from carrier API

NON-RETRYABLE
- invalid ICCID/EID format
- missing identifiers
- policy/compliance blocks

DEFAULTS
- max attempts: 6
- max delay: 5 minutes
- include correlation_id + carrier_transaction_id

TITLE: Circuit Breaker — States and Transitions

SUMMARY
Circuit breaker prevents cascading failures by failing fast when a dependency is unhealthy.

STATES
- Closed: allow requests
- Open: fail fast during cooldown
- Half-open: allow limited probes

TRANSITIONS
- Closed -> Open: error rate exceeds threshold
- Open -> Half-open: cooldown expires
- Half-open -> Closed: probes succeed
- Half-open -> Open: probes fail

TITLE: Change Request — Scope Control Checklist

SUMMARY
Use a change request to control scope and avoid silent timeline/cost creep.

CHECKLIST
- what changed and why
- impact on timeline/cost/risk
- decision: accept / defer / reject
- update scope baseline and milestones

RULE
No change is "free"—always document trade-offs.

TITLE: OTIF — On-Time In-Full Explained

SUMMARY
OTIF measures whether customer orders arrive on time and complete.

WHY IT MATTERS
High OTIF reduces expediting cost and increases customer satisfaction.

LEVERS
- accurate ATP
- safety stock policy
- reliable carriers

TITLE: Project Charter — Minimum Fields

SUMMARY
A one-page charter aligns stakeholders on outcomes and constraints.

MINIMUM FIELDS
- objective + success metrics
- scope (in/out)
- timeline + milestones
- stakeholders + RACI
- top risks + dependencies
